facts.text: Two appellants challenge their conviction by Additional Sessions Judge, No. 1, Jaipur City, for offences under ss. 120B, 420, 420 read with 511, and 467 read with 471, I.P.C., as confirmed by Rajasthan High Court in S. B. Criminal Appeal No. 254 of 1966 dated May 9, 1967.
Bhanwar Singh also convicted for offence under S. 380, I.P.C.
Two appellants along with Kapoorchand and Yasoda Devi tried; latter two acquitted.

Common charge of criminal conspiracy under S. 120B, IPC, to commit theft, pilferage of Indian and British postal orders and bank cheques in transmission by post, erase original payees and post offices, forge names of fictitious persons or accused, use as genuine, present for encashment at post offices and banks at Ajmer and Jaipur through appellants and Yasoda Devi, cheat postal authorities and banks.

Bhanwar Singh charged in pursuance of conspiracy with theft of postal orders and cheques during October 1956 and December 1957, forgery by removing original payees and inserting own name, cheating postal authorities at Jaipur.
Yasoda Devi charged under ss. 467, 471, 420, 419 IPC.

Prosecution case: Bhanwar Singh and Kapoorchand were constables in C.I.D., Ajmer Zone, during 1956-57, pilfered postal orders, British postal orders, cheques while censoring mail, erased original payees and post offices/banks, inserted own or fictitious names, encashed at post offices and banks.
Bhanwar Singh and Kapoorchand conspired with Kishanlal and Yasoda Devi, who encashed the items.
Matter came to light when payees did not receive items and lodged complaints.
Sessions Judge convicted all four: Bhanwar Singh main accused under 380, 467/471, 420/511 r/w 120B; Kishanlal and Yasoda Devi under 467,471,420 r/w 120B; Kapoorchand under 380,467 r/w 120B.
Sentences: various terms of imprisonment and fine, to run concurrently.
High Court: Acquitted Yasoda Devi (evidence insufficient); acquitted Kapoorchand (no sanction u/s 196A CrPC); upheld convictions of appellants.
No sanction obtained under S. 196A CrPC.

legal_issues.text: Whether trial illegal and void for lack of sanction under S. 196A CrPC for offences under ss. 467/471 read with S. 120B IPC, even when charged with cognizable offence under S. 420 IPC.
Whether prosecution evidence establishes guilt of appellants beyond reasonable doubt.

petitioner_arguments.text: Trial illegal and void as no sanction under S. 196A CrPC obtained for non-cognizable offences under ss. 467/471 r/w 120B IPC; joint trial with cognizable S. 420 does not validate.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 196A CrPC; Subbaiah In re (AP HC); Jadeda Meramanji v. State of Gujarat (Guj HC); Nibaran Chandra v. Emperor (Cal HC)

petitioner_arguments.text: Prosecution evidence does not establish guilt.

respondent_arguments.text: Main object of conspiracy was cheating under S. 420 IPC (cognizable, no sanction needed); forgeries under 467/471 incidental to achieve cheating.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S. 120B, 420 IPC; distinction between object and means

court_reasoning.text: Object of conspiracy determined from charges: to cheat banks/post offices under S. 420 r/w 120B (cognizable, punishable >2 years, no sanction needed); forgery/theft means to that end, not separate objects requiring sanction under S. 196A CrPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Difference between object of conspiracy and means adopted; sanction not necessary when object is cognizable offence even if non-cognizable means used.

court_reasoning.text: High Court acquittal of Kapoorchand not binding as he was not convicted under 420 r/w 120B, but appellants were tried for it.
Sessions Judge and High Court elaborately analyzed evidence and found appellants guilty; no error in appreciation.

holdings.text: No sanction under S. 196A CrPC required when conspiracy object is cheating (S. 420 IPC) and non-cognizable forgeries (467/471) are incidental means.
Prosecution evidence sufficient to establish guilt.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave, upheld convictions and sentences of appellants under ss. 120B r/w 420, 467/471 etc. IPC as confirmed by High Court, rejecting contentions on sanction and evidence.

key_quotes.text: It is necessary to keep in mind the difference between the object of a conspiracy and the means adopted for realising that object.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle distinguishing when sanction under S. 196A CrPC is required.

key_quotes.text: The object of the conspiracy has to be determined, not only by reference to the sections of the penal enactment, referred to in the charge, but on a reading of the charges themselves.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains how to identify conspiracy object from charges.

key_quotes.text: A trial, under such circumstances, for offences under s. 120B, read with s. 467/471 and 420 IPC., without obtaining sanction, is neither illegal, nor void.
key_quotes.speaker: court
